body:
I have heard a few users tell me they wish they could use reqwest with a different TLS implementation. While I don't intend for the main `reqwest` crate, as part of the appeal of reqwest is that it Just Works, I have considered some sort of `reqwest-core` crate or something that is all of reqwest without the TLS.

Though, that may be much more than what you're suggesting. I'm not certain yet which would be the easiest or best way forward, but interested in discussing!

>I have heard a few users tell me they wish they could use reqwest with a different TLS implementation. While I don't intend for the main reqwest crate, as part of the appeal of reqwest is that it Just Works

Allowing other TLS implementations doesn't make `reqwest` stop "just working." The most flexible case would be making some sort of interface like `hyper`'s [connectors](https://docs.rs/hyper/0.11.10/hyper/client/struct.HttpConnector.html). A less flexible case would just be using feature gates and implementing other TLS solutions (or having them PR'd in).

In the latter case, using default features, reqwest would function exactly the same. You'd have to opt in to using other TLS implementations (where the API would remain the same). It Just Worksâ„¢.

The only thing stopping me from using `reqwest` is that I can't use `rustls` with it, but I'd really like to use it instead of my hack crate that wraps `hyper` back into blocking mode.

Right. We just had an instance where `reqwest` did not "just work" because it couldn't find the appropriate openssl binding. Using a default of `rustls` would mean that `reqwest` wouldn't be dependent on the system to provide the SSL functionality, making it more "just works". At least making the TLS component plugable allows consumers to choose an alternative, particularly if/when `openssl` is not wanted.

I'd love to find some way to offer reqwest with rustls. Here's some random thoughts:

- reqwest currently defaults to native-tls because it uses mature, reviewed TLS libraries, **and** it works with more of the web (rustls doesn't support older TLS or SSL versions).
- They can't really be cargo features, as features are additive: if one dependency enables the `native-tls` feature, and another enables `rustls`, and they both tried to define what the default TLS was, they would conflict and cause compilation errors.
- They could perhaps become cargo features if they enabled methods on the `ClientBuilder` to be able to pick a TLS backend explicitly. Like, with a `rustls` feature enabled, then `Client::builder().use_rustls().build()` or something. Hm, this might work out OK...

What do you all think of the 3rd point?

I would prefer a `with_backend` function or a `reqwest::backend::rustls::Client` and `reqwest::backend::native_tls::Client`, similar to how `diesel` [handles](https://docs.rs/diesel/1.1.1/diesel/pg/index.html) [different](https://docs.rs/diesel/1.1.1/diesel/sqlite/index.html) [SQL](https://docs.rs/diesel/1.1.1/diesel/mysql/index.html) [backends](https://docs.rs/diesel/1.1.1/diesel/backend/trait.Backend.html).

In addition to being more flexible and extensible (I can make my own implementation of a `Backend` trait for my own custom TLS, etc.), it's more of what I would expect from an API like this, like how `hyper` has connectors.

Also, while supporting more of the web is *good* in a sense, supporting outdated, insecure software is a loss in my book. [Most of the web uses up-to-date protocols at this point, anyway.](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssl-pulse/)

Just out of curiosity, why would you prefer to have strictly typed clients over the just having a `reqwest::Client` that has a boxed TLS implementation inside it?

We could provide a TLS trait (and perhaps typed `Client`s for some backends built-in). Maybe worth starting inside `reqwest::unstable` first?

Really, doing it exactly the same as `diesel` isn't great. Extensible is good, but including TLS options in this crate will fall into the same trap that `hyper` did, where there's code bloat from TLS implementations. Including rustls support in *this* crate is a bad idea, but having a crate like `reqwest_rustls` which provides a backend that can be tied into `reqwest` makes sense.

This feature would be much appreciated, I'm working on a project which requires cross compilation and I'm finding myself trying to decide whether it is worth downloading and compiling OpenSSL from source to get this working. I don't even need TLS for this project as it will be communicating with a local web server only, even an option to disable TLS entirely would be awesome!

I have an amusingly similar use case to @TheLostLambda (porting a mess of shell scripts to rust), and as a rust newbie I'd dearly love to be able to use reqwest for this
I'm currently muddling through with [hyper-rustls](https://crates.io/crates/hyper-rustls) and I do have it working, but it was quite tricky for me to get right
This is what I have so far to download a file to disk, and I haven't even got following redirects working yet: https://github.com/jokeyrhyme/dotfiles-rs/blob/0.6.1/src/utils/http.rs#L12

Specifying TLS backends per-client, combined with making `native-tls` an optional feature, sounds like the best solution to me.

It would be good if attempting to send a TLS request without a provider was a compile-time error. Perhaps by making the provider a type parameter on the client, and only implementing e.g. a `TlsSend` trait on the client if its provider implements e.g. `TlsProvider`? Then a `Client<NoTls>` (or `Client<()>`) can be used when we don't want to include any TLS-providing libraries.

issue.title: Change to work with updated libraries.
Move from hyper to reqwest.
issue.body:
Hyper is now a low-level http library focusing more on asynchronous I/O, updating it doesn't make sense because rust-jsonrpc provides an synchronous API that's more simpler and fits with older hyper versions. Now I propose to move form hyper to reqwest which provides a synchronous API and is similar to older hyper version plus bug-fixes and improvements.

This can be done right now because reqwest includes support for TLS by default and thus including a lot of unneeded libraries for cases where TLS isn't needed (see #7 discussion about this). This upgrade should be done when reqwest adds support for a cargo feature to disable TLS (see seanmonstar/reqwest#225 for the tracking issue).

body: It would be nice to have the ability to disable TLS entirely, even if it's too much design work to make the provider modular. Most applications have no need to directly support TLS (this is what reverse proxies are for), so having the extra code is purely a liability.

issue.title: put all TLS functionality behind a feature flag

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
The "Cargo feature" `default-tls`, which is enabled by default, is
added, with all TLS support relying on it. This allows using reqwest but
disabling the `native-tls` dependency, by disabling this feature.

Closes #225
